content:
ErrorProvider Class

Definition

Provides a user interface for indicating that a control on a form has an error associated with it.

In this Article

[System.ComponentModel.ComplexBindingProperties("DataSource", "DataMember")]
[System.ComponentModel.ProvideProperty("IconPadding", typeof(System.Windows.Forms.Control))]
[System.ComponentModel.ProvideProperty("IconAlignment", typeof(System.Windows.Forms.Control))]
[System.ComponentModel.ProvideProperty("Error", typeof(System.Windows.Forms.Control))]
[System.ComponentModel.ToolboxItemFilter("System.Windows.Forms")]
public class ErrorProvider : System.ComponentModel.Component, System.ComponentModel.IExtenderProvider, System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize
Inheritance
Object
MarshalByRefObject
System.ComponentModel.Component
ErrorProvider

Inherited Members

CanRaiseEvents
Container

MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)

Remarks

ErrorProvider presents a simple mechanism for indicating to the end user that a control on a form has an error associated with it. If an error description string is specified for the control, an icon appears next to the control. The icon flashes in the manner specified by BlinkStyle, at the rate specified by BlinkRate. When the mouse hovers over the icon, a ToolTip appears showing the error description string.

Typically, you use ErrorProvider in association with data-bound controls. When using ErrorProvider with data-bound controls, you must specify the ContainerControl, either in the constructor or by setting the ContainerControl property.

Note

The ErrorProvider component does not provide built-in support for accessibility clients. To make your application accessible when using this component, you must provide an additional, accessible feedback mechanism.

Constructors

ErrorProvider()

Initializes a new instance of the ErrorProvider class and initializes the default settings for stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkRate*, stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkStyle*, and the stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.Icon*.

public ErrorProvider ();

Remarks

The following table shows initial property values for an instance of ErrorProvider.

Property Value
Icon An icon that consists of an exclamation point in a circle with a red background
BlinkRate 250
BlinkStyle ErrorBlinkStyle

ErrorProvider(IContainer)

Initializes a new instance of the ErrorProvider class attached to an IContainer implementation.

public ErrorProvider (System.ComponentModel.IContainer container);
container
IContainer

The IContainer to monitor for errors.

Remarks

The IContainer specified is the container object for the data-bound controls to associate the error provider with.

ErrorProvider(ContainerControl)

Initializes a new instance of the ErrorProvider class attached to a container.

public ErrorProvider (System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl parentControl);
parentControl
ContainerControl

The container of the control to monitor for errors.

Remarks

The Control specified by ContainerControl is the container object for the data-bound controls to associate the error provider with.

Properties

BlinkRate

Gets or sets the rate at which the error icon flashes.

public int BlinkRate { get; set; }
Value
Int32

The rate, in milliseconds, at which the error icon should flash. The default is 250 milliseconds.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

The value is less than zero.

Remarks

The error icon flashes at the specified rate. A value of zero sets BlinkStyle to ErrorBlinkStyle.

BlinkStyle

Gets or sets a value indicating when the error icon flashes.

public System.Windows.Forms.ErrorBlinkStyle BlinkStyle { get; set; }
Value
ErrorBlinkStyle

One of the ErrorBlinkStyle values. The default is ErrorBlinkStyle.

Exceptions
InvalidEnumArgumentException

The assigned value is not one of the ErrorBlinkStyle values.

Remarks

The error icon flashes in the manner specified by the assigned ErrorBlinkStyle when an error occurs. Setting the BlinkRate to zero sets the BlinkStyle to ErrorBlinkStyle.

ContainerControl

Gets or sets a value indicating the parent control for this ErrorProvider.

public System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl ContainerControl { get; set; }
Value
ContainerControl

The ContainerControl that contains the controls that the ErrorProvider is attached to.

Remarks

Typically, this is the Form the data-bound controls reside on.

DataMember

Gets or sets the list within a data source to monitor.

public string DataMember { get; set; }
Value
String

The string that represents a list within the data source specified by the stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource* to be monitored. Typically, this will be a DataTable.

Remarks

The DataMember is a navigation string based on DataSource.

To avoid conflicts at run time that can occur when changing DataSource and DataMember, you should use BindToDataAndErrors instead of setting DataSource and DataMember individually.

DataSource

Gets or sets the data source that the ErrorProvider monitors.

public object DataSource { get; set; }
Value
Object

A data source based on the IList interface to be monitored for errors. Typically, this is a DataSet to be monitored for errors.

Remarks

The DataSource is a data source that you can attach to a control and that you want to monitor for errors. DataSource can be set to any collection that implements IList.

To avoid conflicts at run time that can occur when changing DataSource and DataMember, you should use BindToDataAndErrors instead of setting DataSource and DataMember individually.

Icon

Gets or sets the Icon that is displayed next to a control when an error description string has been set for the control.

public System.Drawing.Icon Icon { get; set; }
Value
Icon

An Icon that signals an error has occurred. The default icon consists of an exclamation point in a circle with a red background.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

The assigned value of the Icon is null.

Remarks

For best results, use an icon of the size 16 x 16 pixels. Specified icons are resized to be 16 x 16 pixels, if necessary.

RightToLeft

Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the component is used in a locale that supports right-to-left fonts.

public virtual bool RightToLeft { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the component is used in a right-to-left locale; otherwise, false.

Remarks

When this property is set to true, the error icon appears to the left of the associated control and the ToolTip text is displayed in right-to-left order.

Site

Gets or sets the ISite of the Component.

public override System.ComponentModel.ISite Site { set; }
Value
ISite

The ISite associated with the Component, or null if the Component is not encapsulated in an IContainer, the Component does not have an ISite associated with it, or the Component is removed from its IContainer.

Tag

Gets or sets an object that contains data about the component.

public object Tag { get; set; }
Value
Object

An object that contains data about the control. The default is null.

Remarks

Use this property to store custom data about the component.

Methods

BindToDataAndErrors(Object,String)

Provides a method to set both the stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource* and stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember* at run time.

public void BindToDataAndErrors (object newDataSource, string newDataMember);
newDataSource
Object

A data set based on the IList interface to be monitored for errors. Typically, this is a DataSet to be monitored for errors.

newDataMember
String

A collection within the newDataSource to monitor for errors. Typically, this will be a DataTable.

Remarks

To avoid conflicts at run time that can occur when changing DataSource and DataMember, you should use BindToDataAndErrors instead of setting DataSource and DataMember individually.

CanExtend(Object)

Gets a value indicating whether a control can be extended.

public bool CanExtend (object extendee);
extendee
Object

The control to be extended.

Returns
Boolean

true if the control can be extended; otherwise, false.

This property will be true if the object is a Control and is not a Form or ToolBar.

Remarks

Typically, you will use CanExtend to determine whether you can attach an ErrorProvider to the specified control.

Clear()

Clears all settings associated with this component.

public void Clear ();

Remarks

Calling this method clears all property settings for this ErrorProvider, restoring the properties to their default values. To clear the error message, call the SetError method and pass in Empty for the String value. This removes the error glyph from the specified Control.

Dispose(Boolean)

Releases the unmanaged resources used by the Component and optionally releases the managed resources.

protected override void Dispose (bool disposing);
disposing
Boolean

true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

GetError(Control)

Returns the current error description string for the specified control.

public string GetError (System.Windows.Forms.Control control);
control
Control

The item to get the error description string for.

Returns
String

The error description string for the specified control.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

control is null.

GetIconAlignment(Control)

Gets a value indicating where the error icon should be placed in relation to the control.

public System.Windows.Forms.ErrorIconAlignment GetIconAlignment (System.Windows.Forms.Control control);
control
Control

The control to get the icon location for.

Returns
ErrorIconAlignment

One of the ErrorIconAlignment values. The default icon alignment is ErrorIconAlignment.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

control is null.

GetIconPadding(Control)

Returns the amount of extra space to leave next to the error icon.

public int GetIconPadding (System.Windows.Forms.Control control);
control
Control

The control to get the padding for.

Returns
Int32

The number of pixels to leave between the icon and the control.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

control is null.

Remarks

Many icons typically have extra space around their central images, so the padding value is only necessary if additional space is necessary. Padding values can be positive or negative. Negative values cause the icon to overlap the edge of the control. The default icon padding is 0.

OnRightToLeftChanged(EventArgs)

Raises the RightToLeftChanged event.

protected virtual void OnRightToLeftChanged (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

A EventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnRightToLeftChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

SetError(Control,String)

Sets the error description string for the specified control.

public void SetError (System.Windows.Forms.Control control, string value);
control
Control

The control to set the error description string for.

value
String

The error description string, or null or String to remove the error.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

control is null.

Remarks

If the length of value is greater than zero, then the error icon is displayed, and the ToolTip for the error icon is the error description text. If the length is zero or value is null, the error icon is hidden.

SetIconAlignment(Control,ErrorIconAlignment)

Sets the location where the error icon should be placed in relation to the control.

public void SetIconAlignment (System.Windows.Forms.Control control, System.Windows.Forms.ErrorIconAlignment value);
control
Control

The control to set the icon location for.

value
ErrorIconAlignment

One of the ErrorIconAlignment values.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

control is null.

Remarks

The final placement of the icon is modified by the icon padding values.

SetIconPadding(Control,Int32)

Sets the amount of extra space to leave between the specified control and the error icon.

public void SetIconPadding (System.Windows.Forms.Control control, int padding);
control
Control

The control to set the padding for.

padding
Int32

The number of pixels to add between the icon and the control.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

control is null.

Remarks

Many icons typically have extra space around their central images, so the padding value is only necessary when additional space is necessary. Padding values can be positive or negative. Negative values cause the icon to overlap the edge of the control.

UpdateBinding()

Provides a method to update the bindings of the stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource*, stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember*, and the error text.

public void UpdateBinding ();

Remarks

Typically, you call this method after you have called BindToDataAndErrors.

Events

RightToLeftChanged

Occurs when the stem.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.RightToLeft* property changes value.

public event EventHandler RightToLeftChanged;

Remarks

For more information about handling events, see Events.

Explicit Interface Implementations

ISupportInitialize.BeginInit()

Signals the object that initialization is starting.

void ISupportInitialize.BeginInit ();

ISupportInitialize.EndInit()

Signals the object that initialization is complete.

void ISupportInitialize.EndInit ();
